title: Goldman Sachs, Twitter, Johnson & Johnson: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

title: AMC Settles 'Walking Dead' Lawsuit for $200 Million
summary: Agreement resolves dispute over profits with the zombie series' executive producer Frank Darabont and the CAA talent agency. AMC Networks Inc. has agreed to pay $200 million to settle a long-running legal battle with "The Walking Dead" executive producer Frank Darabont and Creative Artists Agency LLC over profits from the hit show.

title: President Warren's Government
summary: Her proteges are filling out Biden's business regulatory team.. President Biden defeated Elizabeth Warren in the 2020 Democratic primary by running as a centrist. But you wouldn't know it by the way the Massachusetts Senator is seeding her proteges and allies throughout the administrative state. She has far more sway than Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: Biden's Warning on Hong Kong
summary: The Administration alerts U.S. companies of the new business risks.. Neither China nor Hong Kong authorities have paid much of a price for their assault on the city's autonomy. That may be changing, as a pair of useful actions by the Biden Administration suggest.

title: Censorship Coordination Deepens
summary: The White House says it is 'flagging' Facebook posts on Covid.. The Biden Administration sure isn't taking Donald Trump's Big Tech lawsuits seriously. A week after the former President's lawyers argued in court filings that his removal by social-media firms amounted to "state action," the Administration broadcast that it is coordinating with the firms to remove content.

title: The Stone-Manning Files
summary: A Biden nominee's testimony about her past is directly contradicted.. Senators can disagree over the ideology of nominees, but there at least should be bipartisan trust that an appointee will be honest with Congress. That's become an issue with Tracy Stone-Manning, President Biden's choice to lead the Bureau of Land Management.

title: Three Cheers for Employer Health Insurance
summary: It gets a bum rap. Data demonstrate it delivers great value to companies, employees and taxpayers.. The Covid-19 pandemic has placed enormous stress on the American workforce. Unemployment topped 14 million last spring as businesses and communities locked down. With so many out of work, you'd expect to see a spike in the number of people going without health insurance. Yet the number of people on employer insurance fell only 1% or 2% even as employment dropped 20% at one point.

title: Make Way for the Queens of Chess
summary: Bobby Fischer called women 'terrible chess players,' but 16 American girls are now masters.. This month 10 of the best young female chess players in the country will compete in St. Louis for the title of U.S. Girls' Junior Champion. It is the first in-person national championship among girls since the pandemic moved American chess online in early 2020. It is also the first such championship since the premiere of "The Queen's Gambit," the Netflix hit series about an orphan girl, Beth Harmon, partly based on American chess champ Bobby Fischer, who rises to the pinnacle of the chess world.

title: Progressives Punish 'Honorary Whites' but Aren't Helping Blacks
summary: The bizarre antiwhite racism of the president's pandemic programs is just part of the show.. Like biting into a madeleine was reading a federal court injunction against the Biden administration's pandemic bailout program for restaurants, which favored some ethnicities over others. Memories came flooding back of South Africa's apartheid in its waning days, with its absurd designation of certain Asians as "honorary whites."

title: Notable & Quotable: Civics and 'Equity'
summary: 'Much more needs to be done to center students' race, ethnicity, culture, and identity in the curriculum.'. Justice Sandra Day O'Connorwriting for the Supreme Court in Grutter v. Bollinger (2003):

title: Notable & Quotable: Self-Esteem
summary: 'It is entirely egotistical and self-regarding, unlike self-respect, which is a social virtue and imposes discipline.'. Anthony Danielswriting in the June issue of the New Criterion:

title: Number Puzzles (Saturday, July 17)
Biden Blasts Covid-19 Vaccine Misinformation on Social Media
summary: President says, 'They're killing people,' when asked about Covid-19 vaccine misinformation on online platforms including Facebook. President Biden blasted Facebook and other social-media companies over the spread of misinformation around Covid-19 vaccines on their platforms.

title: Trump Beach Sand Policy Reversed Under Biden
summary: Action followed objections by environmentalists to a change that made it easier for towns to import sand from protected areas. The Biden administration has rescinded a two-year-old policy that allowed beach towns along the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico coasts to use sand from environmentally protected areas in federally funded anti-erosion projects.

title: More California Counties Recommend Face Masks Again
summary: Bay Area officials cite Delta variant, rising Covid-19 cases in asking even fully vaccinated residents to wear masks indoors. LOS ANGELES-One month after California fully reopened for business, many of the state's most populous counties are putting their masks back on.

title: What Is Happening in South Africa? Riots After Jacob Zuma's Arrest
summary: Protests over jailing of former leader spiral into unrest and looting amid a record Covid-19 outbreak. The arrest of former South African President Jacob Zuma this month has triggered looting and violence in the country's two most populous provinces amid a record wave of Covid-19 infections. Current President Cyril Ramaphosa said the unrest was the result of an orchestrated campaign to start an insurrection against South Africa's constitutional order.

title: Stocks Decline, End Week With Losses
summary: Dow, S&P & Nasdaq all dip as investors weighed economic data. U.S. stocks fell and snapped a three-week winning streak as data showed that consumer sentiment dwindled in early July, driven in part by concerns of high inflation.

title: South Africa President Says Rioting Following Predecessor's Arrest Was Attempted Insurrection
summary: At least 212 people have died, more than 2,500 arrested following conviction of former President Zuma. JOHANNESBURG-South African President Cyril Ramaphosa said Friday that the unrest that followed the arrest of his predecessor was a coordinated campaign to start an insurrection against the country's democracy through sabotage of the economy and critical infrastructure.

title: Twitter Adds Captions for Voice Tweets After Criticism
summary: Accessibility advocates said that before the change, voice tweets had excluded deaf people. Twitter Inc. users now have the option of seeing automated captions for voice tweets, a feature the company rolled out in June 2020 without such text, prompting criticism from accessibility advocates and users who said it excluded people who are deaf or hard of hearing.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: Joseph P. Kennedy's diplomatic fiasco; the past and future of quarantines; new fiction from Katie Kitamura; the heroic age of the Tour de France and more..

title: Yield Spread Highlights Embrace of Riskier Debt
summary: Investors scoop up lower-rated debt, pushing yields closer to those of government bonds. The extra return investors demand to hold lower-rated corporate bonds over ultrasafe Treasurys has fallen within striking distance of all-time lows, a sign of investors' appetite for riskier assets and the changing composition of bond indexes.

title: 'The Ambassador' Review: Joseph Kennedy's Diplomatic Disaster
summary: At a fraught moment in history, America's bumptious envoy sided with appeasers and mastered the art of the faux pas.. He was manipulative-and manipulated. He was a boor-and a bore. He had gumption-and guile. He was a vicious infighter-and a reflexive appeaser. He was imperious in manner-and impervious to advice. He was the paterfamilias to a political dynasty-and a notorious philanderer. He was ambitious-and defeatist.

title: 'Until Proven Safe' Review: Quarantines Then and Now
summary: Quarantines of people, produce and even the mail have long been a weapon against infection. They can also be used against people.. In combatting Covid-19, scientists, public health experts and government agencies have occasionally turned to history for counsel. Measures taken, for better or worse, during the Spanish flu of 1918, which infected nearly a third of the world's population, have been particularly influential in the formulation of healthcare policies. No less salutary, oddly, has been guidance from the Middle Ages, an era normally associated with religious mysticism and benighted superstition at the expense of medical science. For upon the advent of the bubonic plague in the 1300s-the notorious Black Death-epidemics began to ravage large parts of Europe, afflicting seaports in the Mediterranean following the arrival of infected ships and their crews from Asia.

title: 'Sprinting Through No Man's Land' Review: The Heroic Age of the Tour de France
summary: France's annual cycling competition has always paid special tribute to the sacrifices of war.. Florid imagery was the hallmark of French journalists who turned the Tour de France, which this year finishes on Sunday in Paris, into Europe's biggest summer soap opera. One of their most evocative terms was hécatombe, or "an extensive loss of life for a particular cause"-in ancient Greece it was a sacrifice of 100 oxen-and cycling scribes have used it ever since to designate those stages of the race when unusually large numbers of riders are eliminated.

title: Fiction: Katie Kitamura's 'Intimacies' Review
summary: Neutrality is a mirage in a tale of a translator in an international court.. The unnamed narrator of Katie Kitamura's novel "Intimacies" (Riverhead, 225 pages, $26) has moved from New York to the Hague to take a temporary position as an interpreter at the International Court of Justice. In that capacity she attends formal arrests and lengthy trials and, in the case of a defiant former West African president being tried for crimes against humanity, closed-door defense counsel meetings, where she sits elbow to elbow beside the accused. The job confronts her with the conundrum always faced by translators, albeit to a heightened degree: She is supposed to function as a kind of invisible conduit through which information passes from one language to another. But such neutrality is an illusion, especially when the discussion turns on extremes of evil that are usually obscured by euphemisms.

title: Lordstown Motors Discloses Justice Department Investigation
summary: Electric-truck startup says probe focuses on matters related to reverse merger deal and preorders for pickup truck Endurance. Electric-truck startup Lordstown Motors Corp. confirmed the Justice Department is probing its business, investigating matters related to its reverse merger deal last year and preorders for its forthcoming pickup truck, the Endurance.

title: The Name of the Game (Saturday Crossword, July 17)
Garden Plot (Saturday Variety Puzzle, July 17)
Is There Ever a Good Time to Investigate Bidens?
summary: Politico hails a prosecutor who delayed the wheels of justice in 2020.. Given the voluminous flow of money collected by various Bidens trading on the family name-and the systematic suppression of this story by the American media-readers can be forgiven for not cheering a prosecutor who declined to press a related investigation during last year's presidential campaign. Readers also have every right to ask what exactly is being done in 2021 to serve the cause of justice. Ben Schreckinger writes in Politico:

title: Missouri Officials File Charges Against Three in Deadly Duck Boat Accident
summary: Federal officials are appealing ruling that tossed their case against captain, two managers. Missouri officials announced charges against a captain and two managers of an amphibious tour-boat company involved in an accident near Branson, Mo., three years ago that killed 17 people.

title: Arrests at U.S.-Mexico Border This Year Top One Million
summary: Surge has posed logistical and political challenges for Biden administration. Border Patrol agents have made more than a million arrests at the U.S.-Mexico border so far this year, already higher than any full-year total since at least 2005, according to new Customs and Border Protection figures released Friday.

title: Children's Books: Seeing the World Through an Artist's Eyes
summary: To lead young readers to art's exuberant pleasures, the painter's brush is the best guide.. The notion that artistic rebels and their fans are somehow superior to the rest of us is, at this point in history, a trope as stale and quaint as a thrift-store antimacassar. Yet the idea persists that traditional paintings and sculptures, and those who like them, are somehow tainted by their attachment to balance and beauty and that, if you want to be one of the cool cats, you had better side with the rule-breakers.

title: A Monumental Miniature
summary: Nicholas Hilliard's 'Young Man Among Roses,' whose subject is likely Robert Deveraux, 2nd Earl of Essex, captures the romantic spirit of the Elizabethan era.

title: Biden to Nominate Ex-Sen. Tom Udall as New Zealand Envoy
summary: The New Mexico Democrat served in the Senate between 2009 and 2021. President Biden will nominate former Democratic Sen. Tom Udall of New Mexico to serve as ambassador to New Zealand and Samoa, the White House said Friday.

title: Mortgage-Refinancing Costs Expected to Fall as Fannie, Freddie Drop Fee
summary: Starting Aug. 1, the government-backed mortgage giants will stop charging a 0.5% refinance fee imposed last year. WASHINGTON-The cost of refinancing government-backed home loans is expected to fall as mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are set to drop a fee imposed last year in the midst of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Sun Bum Is Reviewing Gel Amid Neutrogena Sunscreen Recall
summary: Maker says it is investigating Sun Bum Cool Down gel after report of benzene in some batches. The maker of Sun Bum products said Friday it is investigating the safety of one of its sun-care gels after a potentially cancer-causing chemical was found in some batches.

title: Binance Pulls Plug on Digital Stocks Amid Regulatory Scrutiny
summary: Stock tokens will be unavailable for purchase on the crypto exchange effective immediately, Binance said. Binance Holdings Ltd., the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange operator, said it would stop offering digital tokens tied to stocks like Apple Inc. and Tesla Inc. after regulators in multiple countries raised concerns about the products.

title: U.S. Retail Sales Rose in June
summary: Increased consumer spending, after May's decline, comes amid an acceleration in inflation. Americans stepped up retail spending in June, offering a boost to the economic recovery as it faces concerns about accelerating inflation.

title: Two Charged in Plot to Bomb California Democratic Party Headquarters
summary: Pair used messaging apps to plan attacks after the November 2020 election, starting with John L. Burton Democratic Headquarters in Sacramento. SACRAMENTO, Calif.-Two California men have been charged with plotting to blow up the Democratic Party's headquarters in the state capital, a bombing they hoped would be the first in a series of politically-motivated attacks, federal prosecutors said Thursday.

title: U.S. Warns Businesses Over Rising Risks in Hong Kong
summary: An advisory cautions businesses that operating in Hong Kong carries 'financial, legal and reputational risks'. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is warning American businesses about the increasing risks of operating in Hong Kong as China's tightening grip on the city causes business conditions to deteriorate.

title: The Artistry and Misery of Ivory
summary: A new exhibition in Berlin shows how works of art made of 'white gold' exacted a terrible toll. In the 19th century, hundreds of tons of ivory were shipped from Africa to Europe and the U.S. each year to fabricate everyday objects such as cutlery, piano keys and doorknobs. "Terrible Beauty: Elephant Human Ivory," opening July 20 as the inaugural exhibit at Berlin's new Humboldt Forum museum of non-European art, shows that the insatiable appetite for "white gold" exacted a terrible toll. "It was like an industrial killing of the elephant," said the Forum's director Hartmut Dorgerloh. "Finally elephants became an endangered species in Africa as they'd never been before."

title: FAA Suspends Operations of Crashed Cargo Plane Operator
summary: Agency began investigating Transair's maintenance and safety practices last fall; plane crashed into ocean near Honolulu. The Federal Aviation Administration said it suspended operations of an airline whose cargo plane crashed into the ocean earlier this month, following an investigation into the airline's parent company.

title: Buying a Condo? How to Make Sure the Building is Structurally Sound
summary: Resume Subscription. The collapse of the Champlain Towers South condominium in Surfside, Fla., shows how crucial it is for buyers to not only verify the financial soundness of their future condo association, but the soundness of the building as well.

title: CIOs Faced Trade-Off Between Speed and Perfection in Pandemic Response
summary: So-called technical debt accumulated at some companies as they moved quickly to boost digital capabilities. CIOs spent the past 18 months accelerating their digital projects in response to the effects of the pandemic, but for some, quick fixes could result in more work and expenses down the road.

title: How States That Ended Federal Covid-Related Jobless Benefits Compare With Those That Haven't
summary: Billions of dollars in enhanced federal aid still being paid to jobless Americans, but some states opt out. The number of Americans filing applications for jobless benefits continues to decline to the lowest levels since the economy shut down last year, though claims are still elevated compared with pre-pandemic levels. As many return to work, the amount of federal Covid-era benefits that unemployed people are receiving has splintered from one state to the next.

title: Illinois Democrats Play Politics With the State's Electricity
summary: Their climate bill would raise prices and kill jobs in heavily Republican southern counties.. Illinois doesn't try that hard to attract businesses and workers. Its 9.5% corporate tax rate is the fifth highest in the country. Its property taxes are twice as high as those of its neighbors. And unlike most states in the Midwest, it doesn't have a right-to-work law giving workers the choice not to join a union. Illinois does have one thing going for it: cheap and reliable electricity.

title: The Woke Threat to Philanthropy
summary: Lawmakers and ideologues are growing increasingly insistent in their demands on the nonprofit world.. From Big Tech censorship to Fortune 500 boycotts of Republican-led states, we've heard a lot the past year about "woke capitalism." A related problem is "woke philanthropy": Activists want to tell you not only how to make your money but how to give it away.

title: Wall Street's New Rivalry: Who Can Meet the Most People in Person
summary: Dealmakers get back on the road, and JPMorgan awards points for meetings. The winner gets dinner with the boss.. Wall Street investment bankers are well-accustomed to jockeying for multimillion-dollar fees on corporate deals. Now, the game is focused on just showing up.

title: Don't Believe the Inflated Yields on Inflation-Protected Bond Funds
summary: An 8% return on government bonds? Only a nutty calculation can make it so.. Inflation heated up again this week, but it's nowhere near as hot as funds specializing in bonds that fight it.

title: Goldbelly's Joe Ariel Is Bringing Foodies and Restaurants Together
summary: Rejected '50 or 60' times by potential investors, his idea for a national delivery platform proved its appeal during the pandemic. In 2012, when Joe Ariel was trying to get the restaurant delivery service Goldbelly off the ground, scores of potential investors told him his plan was misguided. A renowned venture capitalist for food-based startups declared that his business model was "stupid."

title: Scholar Led London Stock Exchange Into Modern Era
summary: Nicholas Goodison, a cerebral stockbroker who has died at age 87, oversaw transition to a more global and competitive market. Nicholas Goodison, a self-described "academic chap" who would have seemed more at home in a university library than on a trading floor, led the London Stock Exchange into a far more competitive era in 1986.

title: Iceland Is Open to U.S. Travelers-and Gloriously Uncrowded
summary: For their first overseas trip since the start of the pandemic, a couple heads to Iceland to get far off the tourist track and binge on natural wonders. IT'S ONE OF those end-of-the-earth places. The westernmost part of Iceland that overlooks the frigid Atlantic is a primordial world of sharp, snow-capped peaks, moonlike landscapes and sparkling fjords. But that wasn't the main reason we drove three nerve-racking hours one way over hairpin-curve mountain roads, many unpaved and nearly all with a disturbing lack of guardrails. We wanted to see the puffins.

title: Jeff Bezos, Richard Branson and Where Space Really Begins
summary: Trips by Virgin Galactic and Blue Origin are highlighting the fact that there are different definitions of where space starts. Scientists say determining the boundaries of space is fuzzy, but billionaires Jeff Bezos and Richard Branson have ignited the debate as they race to jump-start a space-tourism industry.

title: America's Spending Recovery Isn't Uniform
summary: Americans are spending more, but not on everything. Retail sales picked back up in June. But just as important as how much money Americans spent last month is where they spent it.

title: The War on Bright, Hard-Working Asian Students
summary: Asian-Americans earn their way into top schools like Stuyvesant and Thomas Jefferson the old-fashioned way-on merit.. After Idi Amin's 1972 ultimatum, my family left Uganda in the Indian exodus with $500, two suitcases and a plane ticket. Purged in an overt act of discrimination and escaping with our lives, we ran from the country we had helped build for generations. Now discrimination against Asians will again affect my family. William McGurn's "A PTA Purge of Asians" (Main Street, July 13) presents clear evidence of discrimination in the name of equity.

title: Inheritance, Inequity and the Baby Boomers
summary: After a double whammy of denied access, most black Americans weren't able to build 'huge old wealth' or leave it to their heirs.. As I read "Huge Old Wealth Gets New Owners" (Page One, July 3), I can't help but focus on this sentence: "The transfer will provide another display of the outsize economic power of baby boomers, who came of age during a wave of post-World War II prosperity and drove the economy through many stages of their lives."

title: Is Ranked-Choice Voting the New American Way?
summary: In Portland, Maine, the Democratic Socialists gamed the system perfectly.. Harvey Mansfield's op-ed "Ranked-Choice Is Bad for Everyone" (July 8) is spot on. I've seen how flawed ranked-choice voting can be. Voters in Portland, Maine, went to the polls June 8 to elect a commission to rewrite the city's charter. The Democratic Socialists gamed the system perfectly. Their candidates ran as a group, the Rose Slate, and encouraged voters who supported any of their four candidates to list the other three as their second, third and fourth choices. In a crowded field, they swept all four at-large seats.

title: Women in Saudi Arabia to Embark on Hajj Without Men for the First Time
summary: Resume Subscription. JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia-When Lina Mokhtar and her two sisters saw the news last month that Saudi Arabia would for the first time officially allow women to perform the hajj without a male guardian, the three of them immediately put in their applications.

title: 'Sob Rock' by John Mayer Review: Not Quite Worth the Tears
summary: With 'Sob Rock,' John Mayer continues to play it safe in his solo career.. There's always been an odd contrast between John Mayer as the public figure and John Mayer as the solo artist. In the decade after his multi-platinum 2001 debut album, "Room for Squares," he was a highly visible celebrity who penned an Esquire column, tried his hand at stand-up, and became a tabloid fixture for dating women even more famous than he was.

title: Hit Hard by Covid-19, Southeast Asian Countries Turn to Western Vaccines
summary: Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines plan to get millions of doses later this year. Developing countries in Southeast Asia are increasingly turning to Western vaccines as the pace of immunizations slows in the U.S. and supplies open up, marking a shift from a reliance on Chinese vaccines earlier in the year.

title: Iran's Nuclear Advances Complicate Biden's Bid to Revive 2015 Deal
summary: Western officials say Tehran's progress could shorten the time it would take to amass enough fissile material for a nuclear weapon under a revived deal. BRUSSELS-Over the past year, Iran has made significant advances in its ability to amass enriched uranium, complicating the Biden administration's effort to revive a 2015 deal aimed at curbing Tehran's atomic ambitions.

title: China Targets Another Region in Ethnic Assimilation Campaign: Tibet
summary: Resume Subscription. MAQEN, China-A quiet state-run campaign is ramping up the assimilation of one of China's most recognizable minorities.

title: Do All the Billionaires Belong in Space?
summary: Branson and Bezos are chasing the next frontier, but it might not be for everyone. If you're a billionaire, everybody's probably asking you when you're going up to space, and I bet it's starting to get irritating. You've made all this money: You've bought the mansion, the other mansion, the other other mansion, the aerie, the idyll, the plane, the seaplane, the helicopter, the yacht, the vineyard, the NFL team, the Renoir, the T-Rex fossil...and now, suddenly, you're supposed to build a rocket, put on a goofy suit and shoot yourself into space.

title: 'Illuminating Natural History' Review: Bringing the New World Into the Light
summary: Mark Catesby's spirit of adventure led him from his small town in England to the New World. His visions of its wildlife endure.. In September 1725, stretched out on the deck of his sloop anchored near Andros Island in the Bahamas, the English naturalist Mark Catesby was gazing at the dark sky above. For three nights he had been listening to flocks of bobolinks passing by, their characteristic calls vanishing into the distance. Having gobbled up all the rice in Cuba, they appeared to be in a hurry to get to the Carolinas, where they would, in just a couple of days, continue their ravages, "the Rice there being, at that time fit for them." Catesby's watercolor of two of these "Rice-Birds"-the more colorful male bending forward to eat, the female clutching the stalk of a rice plant as if it were her lifeline-reflects the bemused wonder with which Catesby viewed their lives. The drawing served as the basis for plate 14 of Catesby's monumental "Natural History of Carolina, Florida, and the Bahama Islands" (1731-43), a collection of 200 incandescent engravings featuring New World fauna and flora, along with field notes in both English and French, one of the most magnificent natural-history books of all time, a worthy predecessor to Audubon's "Birds of America."

title: Mysteries: 'Dead by Dawn' Review
summary: A game warden's interest in a cold case puts him in the crosshairs.. Tired of yourstay-at-home psychological thriller, where all the suspense plays out in the mind of a suburban voyeur? Hungry for action, adventure and physical danger? Take a Jeep ride with 31-year-old Maine game warden Mike Bowditch, the narrator of Paul Doiron's "Dead by Dawn" (Minotaur, 294 pages, $27.99).

title: Some Police Push Back on Bail Reform, Citing Wave of Killings
summary: Law enforcement increasingly calling on judges to hold more violent suspects pending trial; Advocates say pretrial release is responsible for only a small number of crimes. Law-enforcement officials in Chicago say judges need to stop releasing accused violent offenders before their trials to help stem a surge in violent crime.

title: 'Dweller in Shadows' Review: Gifted and Tormented
summary: Ivor Gurney survived the trenches of World War I. But his talents in verse and music couldn't hold off the deterioration of his mind.. In December 1922, the young poet and composer Ivor Gurney (1890-1937) was folded into a hired car by two attendants and driven from his home in Gloucestershire, a rural county northwest of London, to Stone House, a mental hospital in Kent, along England's eastern coast. Out the car window was the landscape that he loved so dearly-the boxy cathedral where he learned to play the organ, the River Severn, and the earth that "entered into my making and into my blood," as he wrote in one of his poems. Indeed, it was this landscape that had inspired much of his most striking verse. As Kate Kennedy notes in "Dweller in Shadows" (Princeton, 459 pages, $35), her poignant biography of Gurney, he would never see it again.

title: 'The Hero's Way' Review: On Garibaldi's Trail
summary: In the long fight for Italian independence known as the Risorgimento, few understood the value of endurance as thoroughly as Giuseppe Garibaldi.. Admirers of the British writer Tim Parks might find his latest nonfiction book, "The Hero's Way" (Norton, 384 pages, $27.95) a surprise. For 40-odd years he has written about his adopted country, Italy, almost always from the point of view of the stranger who has chosen to live there but who continues to notice the things they do differently. His latest novel (last year's "Italian Life") uses Italian words as chapter titles, making the point that certain words express concepts that can be understood only by long immersion in Italian culture. The viewpoint is understanding, affectionate even-but one senses an ironic and occasionally caustic detachment.

title: Five Best: Collections of American Humor
summary: Selected by Adam Gopnik, the editor, most recently, of 'S.J. Perelman: Writings' in the Library of America series.. By S.J. Perelman (1957)

title: What to Know About J&J's Recall of Some Sunscreen Products
summary: Johnson & Johnson said consumers should stop using five of its six Neutrogena and Aveeno spray sunscreens and discard them. Johnson & Johnson on Wednesday said it is recalling most of its Neutrogena and Aveeno spray sunscreens from U.S. stores after detecting benzene, a potentially cancer-causing chemical, in some samples.

title: Is Pope Francis Leading the Church to a Schism?
summary: Resume Subscription. German Catholics have been meeting since last year to consider major changes to church life, including the blessing of same-sex relationships and the ordination of women-moves that many see as essential reforms after the clerical sex-abuse crisis. But the effort has drawn fierce criticism.

title: Hedge Funds Short ESG Market Darling
summary: Payroll lender won over foreign investors by promising to lend to Mexico's underbanked poor, but some now question its financial reporting.. Mexico's largest payroll lender has had a tough year. Wall Street short sellers are betting it's going to get worse.

title: Company PACs Resume Donations to Republicans Who Rejected Election Results
summary: PACs for American Airlines, GM and UPS donated to some GOP lawmakers after pausing all contributions in response to Jan. 6 Capitol riot. WASHINGTON-Big names in corporate America have resumed donating to Republican lawmakers who voted against certifying President Biden's victory after the companies earlier announced pauses or reviews of their political donations in response to the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

title: How to Dip a Toe Into Bitcoin
summary: What to buy, how much to invest and when to rebalance: a guide for the crypto-curious. Does bitcoin belong in your financial plan?

title: Pope Francis Lets Bishops Ban Old Latin Mass
summary: Pontiff said the freedoms allowed by his predecessor to build church unity have instead led to division. ROME-Pope Francis allowed local bishops to ban priests from celebrating the traditional Latin Mass, undoing a liberalization that was one of the major acts of his predecessor, Pope Benedict XVI.

title: Food Entrepreneur Promoted Health Benefits
summary: Robert M. Harris, who has died at age 95, created Smart Balance and Grain Berry brands. When Robert M. Harris launched his own food company in 1973, he had a personal mission as well as a business plan.

title: Twitter's Pulse Rests in Fleet
summary: Twitter is working to better the public conversation. But first, it must understand it. Twitter is about putting yourself out there. A select few fly, most get ignored and the unlucky get canceled.

title: Five Professionals in Their Mid-20s Share How They Landed Their Dream Jobs
summary: These young workers agree: Relationships are the key to a successful job hunt.. Rarely have recent college graduates faced an employment landscape as tumultuous as the current one.

title: Intel CEO's Chip-Building Plan Has a $50 Billion-Plus Price Tag
summary: GlobalFoundries acquisition would bring know-how to Intel's ambitions in third-party chip production. Less than six months into the job, Intel Corp. Chief Executive Officer Pat Gelsinger's approach to reviving the chipmaker's fortunes is emerging: move quickly and carry a big checkbook.

title: Ericsson Warns China Backlash Threatens Its Market Share
summary: After Sweden banned China's Huawei, Beijing indicated it could retaliate. Ericsson AB said revenue in China dropped sharply in the most recent quarter and warned it would likely lose market share there as a consequence of Sweden's decision to ban rival Huawei Technologies Co. from the Scandinavian country's 5G wireless networks.

title: The Key to Avoiding Future Climate Disasters? Adapting
summary: Wildfires, floods and other crises are influenced by climate change, but we can do much more to save lives and property by focusing on urgent practical changes on the ground. In recent years, it has become commonplace to assign at least partial responsibility for many disasters to climate change. This past month alone, the long-term effects of greenhouse-gas emissions were said to be a key factor in the death and destruction caused by the heat wave that scorched the Pacific Northwest, the property damage from record floods in Japan and even the tragic condominium collapse in Miami, because of the destabilizing effect of rising sea levels.

title: Intel Could Find a New World of Complications
summary: Chipmaker's purchase would be a jump into contract manufacturing that could also bring new problems. Pat Gelsinger is wasting no time putting his money where his mouth is.

title: Poised for a Career in Tech Sales, He Founded a Chocolate-Milk Startup Instead
summary: Josh Belinsky already had years of sales experience when he co-founded a beverage company. A string of internships during college and a job at a tech startup had already positioned Josh Belinsky for a promising career in sales by the time he graduated from Northeastern University.

summary: Fathom is combining with the SPAC Altimar Acquisition Corp. II. Fathom Digital Manufacturing Corp. is combining with a special-purpose acquisition company to go public in a deal that values the 3-D printing firm at about $1.4 billion, the companies said.

summary: Resume Subscription. PERHAPS YOU'VE hit a milestone-a new job, an anniversary, a first pregnancy. Perhaps you've stumbled upon a watch enthusiast's Instagram feed and are intrigued. Not an Apple Watch or a Swatch-not that there's anything wrong with them-but something that requires a sizable budget and a commitment. But where to begin?

title: Covid-19 Immune Response Could Be Long Lasting, but Variants Present Risks
summary: Studies show that variants including Delta can partially evade immune response from infection and vaccination. Infection and inoculation both elicit an immune response against Covid-19 that lasts for months and possibly years, a growing body of research shows, but the power of vaccines against known variants make the shots critical to containing the virus.

title: England's Other Sports Drought: Winning the British Open
summary: Days after the English football team's loss, the British Open is an opportunity for the country to end another historic dry spell.. The Three Lions were playing on home soil. Football was coming home.

title: 2022 Indian Chief Bobber Dark Horse: Styled to Throw Shade
summary: The pared-back motorcycle, which takes matte-black styling to a monochromatic extreme, offers a stark counterpoint to Harley-Davidson's traditional chrome brightwork. IF WE MEASURED motorcycles' badassery like pool pH, we would hold their litmus strips against a grayscale running from chrome to black. In the visual code of street bikes, less chrome reads as younger, cooler, more outlaw and-here's the salient point-less like Harley-Davidson . In the years after 2008, Harley's traditionally over-splendid brightwork came to be associated with the brand's steep prices and the graying clientele.

title: Paytm Parent Plans $2.2 Billion IPO in India
summary: One97 Communications boasts more than 330 million customers. NEW DELHI-The company behind Indian mobile-payment app Paytm plans to raise up to $2.2 billion through one of India's largest-ever initial public offerings, capitalizing on a boom in the country's stock market.

summary: Only Tesla has convinced Chinese consumers that its offerings can match the local competition. But other than Tesla Inc., foreign makers have failed to convince Chinese consumers that their EVs match the local competition.

title: Russia Emerges as Key Backer of Myanmar's Military Post-Coup

summary: Fears of a cyclical peak are weighing on semiconductor stocks even as a shortage helps keep sales brisk. Chip companies face a challenging task heading into the next round of quarterly reports: Great numbers may only add to investors' fears that a peak is coming.

title: Beijing Calls Time on Big Tech's Shopping Spree
summary: Mergers and acquisitions in China aren't totally going away, but the free-for-all of days past is over. title: China Sends State Security, Police Officials to Didi for Cybersecurity Probe
summary: The stationing of regulators at the ride-hailing firm is the latest development in saga that has gripped the country's tech industry. title: Auto Loans Are Getting Off the Beaten Track
summary: Lenders are cushioning the impact of high sticker prices on cars with longer, cheaper loans. Prices of new and used vehicles are at record highs, bolstered by a semiconductor supply crunch that has kept a lid on car production just as consumers are itching to get out and shop for them. Used cars and trucks were 45.2% more expensive in June than they were a year earlier, while new cars were 5.3% pricier, according to the Labor Department. Monthly payments don't look all that different to consumers, though, thanks to lower rates, longer terms, or putting up more cash. For new cars, average monthly loan payments increased just $7 in the first quarter of 2021 compared with a year earlier, according to consumer-credit reporting company Experian . Monthly loan payments for used cars rose $19, or 5%, in the same period.

title: Hurricane Katrina Wasn't the First Storm to Use That Name, but It Was the Last
summary: Most hurricane names are reused; Elsa blew in for the first time this year. By the time Elsa-the first Atlantic hurricane of the season-blew into Florida this month, it had been downgraded to a tropical storm whose damage, compared with the most devastating cyclones in U.S. history, was slight. And because of that, its name might get reused.

title: Sovereign-Wealth Funds Invest More at Home as Covid-19 Hits Economies
summary: The behemoth investors, which manage trillions of dollars for nations, are looking inward as countries reboot from the pandemic. title: London Borough of Hackney Struggles With Recovery Months After Ransomware Attack
summary: Some ransomware victims deal with IT problems and backlogged work for long periods after an attack. title: Groups on Both Sides of Abortion Debate Prepare for 2022 Battle
summary: Susan B. Anthony List plans campaign aimed at blunting President Biden's ability to appoint judges. ANTIABORTION GROUP SUSAN B. ANTHONY LIST plans to mount a $73 million campaign in the 2022 midterms to topple Democratic congressional majorities, especially in the Senate to blunt President Biden's ability to appoint judges. The group spent $61.5 million to re-elect former President Donald Trump and a Republican Senate in 2020. It sees a decadeslong effort to install an antiabortion judiciary and build power at the state level nearing its pinnacle with a 6-3 conservative Supreme Court advantage and a slew of challenges to Roe v. Wade coming through the litigation pipeline.

summary: As in many countries, some Indian states and hospitals are incorporating telemedicine into their pandemic plans. One harried doctor, Mr. Manem said, carved out five minutes to chat over the phone.

title: Dozens Dead, Many More Missing in Heavy Flooding Across Europe
summary: Catastrophic rainfall across Germany, Belgium and France as scientists say extreme weather is becoming more frequent. Dozens of people were feared dead and many more were missing as the worst flooding in decades caused houses to collapse in Germany, Belgium and other parts of western Europe following days of heavy rain that swelled rivers and overloaded sewage systems.

title: Three Large Hospitals Won't Give New Alzheimer's Drug
summary: The three hospital operators are holding off on administering Aduhelm amid a debate over its effectiveness.
